awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Testing the Drivers and Scale-dependency of Plant-fungal Bacterial Community Co-assembly Across the Arctic
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposed Award Abstract

Arctic vegetation is rapidly changing in response to broad-scale Arctic warming.  The investigators of this proposal argue that only by exploring how plants, soil microbes, and soil fungal communities interact and evolve together can we truly understand how vegetation may change in the future.  Using over 3500 soil samples that have been collected across the arctic, along with environmental and plant data at the same sites, the investigators will employ new genetic and statistical techniques to understand the complex plant-microbe-fungal relations.  While the work tackles a number of basic ecological questions, it will also provide insights into the controls determining how vegetation may change in the near future.

The University of New Mexico is a certified Hispanic Serving Institution and of the 1600 undergraduate Biology majors, over 30% are Hispanic.  Taylor and Takacs-Vesbach will provide project related research experience to these and other under-represented students.  Taylor and Takacs-Vesbach are currently mentor students through three STEM programs based in the Biology department.  A letter of support is provided by the Director of the UNM Minority Access to Research Careers (MARC) Program, which commits him to helping the program recruit MARC Program Scholars for training in microbiome methods. The proposal includes for the training of a female post-doctoral scientist at the University of Alaska, Fairbanks.

The investigators pose a series of hypotheses that focus on the ecological drivers of community assembly (dispersal, environmental filtering, competition, facilitation, niche partitioning, neutral processes) across five Arctic biomes.   They will use over 3500 soil samples that have been collected along two latitudinal transects, each of which includes all five Arctic bioclimatic subzones and spans 1700 kilometers north to south.  Using their extensive sampling and next-generation-sequencing-derived data on community composition of soil fungi and bacteria that are already in hand, combined with data on plant communities at the same sites (which will be augmented with limited sequencing of plant phylogenetic markers), the investigators seek to examine the fundamental patterns of community assembly in each of the three Kingdoms at hierarchical spatial and ecological scales.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to examine the fundamental patterns of community assembly of plants, fungi and bacteria at hierarchical spatial and ecological scales across the Arctic. We were using our extensive sampling and data from massive next-generation sequencing for fungi and bacteria. Furthermore, using our extensive ecological metadata, we wanted to determine the roles of stochastic versus deterministic forces, abiotic controls and biological interactions in the community assembly of Plant-Fungal-Bacterial communities across the Arctic.

 

Our results show that across and along the two Arctic transects, plant and fungal communities are significantly structured by transects, subzones and a complex of abiotic filters. Climate represented the strongest filter, followed by soil pH and soil texture. These effects were generally more pronounced for plant communities than for fungal communities. The assembly of plant and fungal communities at the local scale are more affected by stochastic processes, while deterministic processes shape the communities at a regional scale from subzone to transect. Along the bioclimatic gradients, temperature showed an increasing control over community assembly from the warmer to the coldest subzones. However, in the coldest subzones pH, soil carbon related factors and volumetric soil moisture having a stronger control over plant and fungal community composition than temperatures.

In 2016, we had an opportunity to re-sample three of our most northern sites in the High Canadian Arctic, which underwent natural dramatic thermokarst after our initial sampling in 2006. Therefore, we could assess the effect of recent climate warming on these most northern sites. Our analysis of the soil factors shows significant increase of soil moisture (%) in the thermokarst areas compared to the adjacent areas that are not affected by thermokarst. Changes in soil characteristics, such as pH and soil nutrients, were most pronounced in the most northern sites at bioclimatic subzone A. Furthermore, our analyses showed that fungal communities responded with significant changes to thermokarst. Soil fungal communities significantly shifted in taxonomic (phyla, classes) and functional composition (guilds, trophic mode) from 2006 to 2016 and among the thermokarst regimes in 2016. Overall, the changes were most pronounced in the two coldest bioclimatic subzones of the Arctic.

 As part of our public outreach, we carved an ice sculpture ?Microcosm? (3.5*3*2.5 meters) at the Ice Art World Championship in Fairbanks. The sculpture depicted fungal and bacterial communities in Arctic soils and was accompanied by a poster which answered a series of questions about soil microbes in the Arctic. This event was visited by approximately 45,000 people.

 

Finally, we contributed to three publications during the time of funding and submitted most of the available data to the Arctic Data Center.
